Samantabhadra Bodhisattva replied:
Excellent question! Listen carefully and keep it in mind.
He replied:
Yes, indeed.
Samantabhadra said:
Bodhisattvas have ten kinds of physical actions.
What are the ten?
They are able to pervade the Buddha-realm with one body, thus it is called physical action;
manifesting the gates of all realms of sentient beings;
dwelling together with all beings;
wandering alone in the worlds of the ten directions;
also going to all the Buddha's places of assembly and places of Dharma-turning;
able to cover all the trichiliocosm with one hand, and hold the great iron-encircling mountains and vajra-mountains with one palm;
displaying all the Buddha-lands within the body to sentient beings;
and causing them to dissolve;
accepting the realm of sentient beings in one body, concealing and dwelling alone;
and also manifesting all sentient beings being enlightened in one's own body, in order to accomplish the adornment and purification of the Buddha-land;
these are the ten physical actions.
Bodhisattvas abide in this and thereby attain the unsurpassed Buddha-action, instructing all beings so that they may reach the Way.
There are ten things in the essence of a bodhisattva.
What are the ten?
The essence is able to respectfully cultivate the six pÄramitÄs;
Able to practice the four kinds of kindness, not abandoning sentient beings;
Cultivating unobstructed compassion, on behalf of all beings, one's own body receives it;
The suffering burden of the five aggregates is not weary;
The body of infinite kindness universally protects all, enabling them to attain liberation;
Using the form of merit, causing all people to be able to revere and respect it, and attain peace and liberation;
Using the affairs of holy wisdom - because all buddhas are of the same essence - one attains accomplishment;
Abandoning all perilous and dangerous dharmas, this is called the Dharma body;
Skillful means, all manifested gates, spiritual powers, and transformations are all able to reveal;
What moves the essence of a bodhisattva is being sovereign in the Way, and then attaining perfect enlightenment;
These are the ten essences.
If bodhisattvas abide in this, they will be able to enter the TathÄgata's unsurpassed great wisdom.
Bodhisattvas have ten kinds of speech.
What are the ten?
Their speech is truthful, and they use this teaching to bring peace to sentient beings;
Their speech is gentle, pleasing the thoughts of all people;
Their speech is not false, speaking as they say, and uttering sincere words;
Bodhisattvas are like this, even in dreams they have no different speech;
What they say accords with reality, not deceiving Åšakra, BrahmÄ, or the Four Heavenly Kings;ğŸ”½Their speech is profound and wonderful, without harm, able to reveal the natural teaching;
Their speech is firm, proclaiming the Dharma without bounds;
The path they expound follows all words and uses them to transform;
According to people's actions, they speak of their retributions and show their origins and ends;
Observing the thoughts of the assembly, they teach in accordance with their capacities;
These are the ten kinds of speech of the bodhisattvas.
Bodhisattvas have ten kinds of pure conduct.
What are the ten?
They delight in hearing the sound of the TathÄgata's voice, which is pure;
They contemplate the sounds that bodhisattvas have heard, and avoid those that sentient beings do not delight in hearing, abandoning evil speech and not inflicting it upon others;
They always stay far away from the four kinds of verbal faults that were spoken of in the past;
With a joyful mind, they praise the TathÄgata and proclaim the great sound;
In the Buddha's divine temples, they sing praises of the Buddha's virtues;
With a pure and harmonious nature, they proclaim the Dharma for the sake of sentient beings;
In the venerable divine temples, they make various kinds of music, such as lutes, zithers, and flutes, to delight the Buddha's stÅ«pas;
They personally attend to the buddhas, the world-honored ones, and listen to the sÅ«tras;
They follow the blessings of the heavens and the bodhisattvas;
If they hear the sÅ«tras because of the Dharma master, they personally serve him, and their minds let go of the heavens;
These are the ten ways in which the bodhisattvas' teachings are well-purified.
Bodhisattvas have ten things that they protect and embrace well.
What are the ten?
The heavenly kings appear and all protect them;
The dragon kings and ghost kings all come out to guard them;ğŸ”½The gandharvas and asuras all come to pay homage;
The garuá¸as and golden-winged bird kings all come to comfort them;
The kiá¹ƒnaras and mahoragas all look up to them;
Moreover, the Heavenly Emperor Åšakra and the heavenly retinue all come to protect them;
The BrahmÄ kings, together with the BrahmÄ heavens, take refuge in the side;
The bodhisattvas all respectfully think of them;
Those who are not in retrogression and are one life away from Buddhahood all come to be close to them;
The tathÄgatas in the ten directions all use their awesome spiritual power to protect them;
These are the ten ways that bodhisattvas protect and gather in goodness.
Bodhisattvas have ten things that they cultivate and study.
What are the ten?

Always encouraging and delighting the realm of sentient beings, also teaching and transforming the buddhas and lands in the trichiliocosm, and being able to enter all faculties, whether sharp, dull, or in between, and adorning and purifying according to their lands, eliminating all afflictions of love and desire, distancing oneself from defilements, abandoning the realm of objects while still being able to see where the mind is, gradually increasing the nature of purity and peace, and thus being able to reach throughout the Dharma realm, for this reason quickly approaching nirvÄá¹‡aâ€”these are the ten.
Bodhisattvas have ten things in their impartial mind.
What are the ten?
The impartial mind of dhÄraá¹‡Ä«, upholding all sentient beings, gathering the roots of virtue, not letting them be lost;
The mind like a river or sea, immeasurable, in accord with the buddhas' Dharma, the wisdom of the boundless path;
The mind like Mount Sumeru, its virtue surpassing, establishing all the roots of virtue for sentient beings;
The mind is like a bright pearl, removing all impurities, and the mind is pure;
The mind is like a diamond, destroying all flawed dharmas;
The mind is as firm as the Iron-Encircling Mountains, indestructible, and no demons or non-Buddhist teachings can move it;
The bodhisattva's mind is like a lotus, wandering in the three realms without ever being attached;
The bodhisattva's mind is like a rare flower, difficult to see or hear for countless eons;
The mind is like the sun's light, traveling through the sky, eliminating all darkness, obstructions, and ignorance;
The mind is like space, having compassion for all beings;
These are the ten minds of the bodhisattva.
The bodhisattva's resolve has ten things.
What are the ten?
The resolve is to think:
'I will bring joy to all beings, and I will completely eliminate the afflictions and desires of all sentient beings, leaving no remainder.'
He further thought:
'I will cut off all obstructions and difficulties, and in all dharmas I will not be doubtful, and I will attain tranquility.'
'I will alleviate the suffering of the five aggregates of all sentient beings, and I will eliminate the evil destinies and the eight difficulties.'
'I will always see all tathÄgatas, and I will never leave their side;
I will always diligently study the bodhisattva precepts and accomplish the path of the buddhas.'
'I will see all sentient beings, accomplish all, and cause them to enter the path, and therefore I give rise to the intention.'

You should know that the ultimate Dharma drum universally pervades the buddha-lands of the ten directions, and it completely encompasses the minds, natures, and faculties of the people, leaving none out.ğŸ”½These are the ten matters of the bodhisattva's giving rise to the intention.
The bodhisattva's intention is also tenfold.
What are the ten?
The mind is all-pervading, vast like empty space;
Entering the immeasurable Dharma realm of all dharmas, in a single instant pervading the three times;

The arising of the buddhas is able to fully enter the womb, be born, abandon the country and renounce the king, attain supreme perfect enlightenment, and manifest great nirvana, all due to the holy wisdom;
Entering the realm of sentient beings, understanding their mental dispositions, and awakening to their faculties;
With the holy light reaching everywhere in all Dharma realms, pervading the boundless;
The nets of illusions arise from nowhere;
Reaching naturalness without inversion, beyond calculation;
One's own mind is unobstructed, causing others to be free from obstruction;
With the light of wisdom attaining mastery;
When the buddhas arise, wherever the mind is directed, supreme perfect enlightenment is manifested;
These are the ten ways the bodhisattva's mind is all-pervading.
The bodhisattva's faculties have ten matters.
What are the ten?
When the bodhisattvas see the buddhas, their faculties are delighted and they are overjoyed and do not turn back;
They delight in the buddhas, revere the sÅ«tras, and understand everything;
The bodhisattvas do not turn back any of the faculties, and there is nothing that obstructs them;
Their minds always firmly abide, and the practices they cultivate cannot be destroyed;
Their faculties are subtle and they understand and distinguish the perfection of wisdom;
The minds of the bodhisattvas do not advance or retreat, and they exhort sentient beings with a will like vajra;
They digest all dharmas and destroy various evils. Their light is firm and strong, illuminating everywhere;
They see the radiance of the tathÄgatas and their faculties are not surprised;
The minds of the bodhisattvas understand the tathÄgata's body to be combined into a single essence;
The minds of the bodhisattvas reach the limitless realm and enter the tathÄgata's ten powers;
These are the bodhisattvas' ten faculties.
Bodhisattvas have ten kinds of resolve.
What are the ten?
There are bodhisattvas whose minds are always unattached, not greedy for worldly things;
Their minds are clear and penetrating, not mixed up, not thinking of the matters of Å›rÄvakas and pratyekabuddhas;
Moreover, it is said that the bodhisattva's disposition is gentle and compliant, always aspiring to the Buddha's path;
His mind is pure and harmonious, and he is born from the knowledge of all modes;
What he thinks is without compare, subduing the mÄras and non-Buddhist teachings;
His aspirations are without fault, purifying all the TathÄgata's wisdom fields;
He always skillfully rescues and embraces the fundamental and ultimate of his mind;
He never forgets the Dharma as he has heard it;
His mind is naturally without reliance or attachment, and he has no preferences for where he is born;
His aspirations are profound and wondrous, able to enter into wondrous wisdom, thinking of and believing in the Buddha's teachings;
These are the ten natures of the bodhisattva.
The bodhisattva's disposition has ten things.
What are the ten?
The nature of a bodhisattva is to be intent on the noble and not to regress;
Accumulating all virtuous and wholesome dharmas, not doubting the buddhas;
Praising the TathÄgata's fundamental nature and conduct, abiding in the comprehensive;
Practicing as a great teacher, hearing and fulfilling one's vows;
Remembering the crown protuberance, able to pervade everywhere, in the naturally pure nature of the buddhas' dharmas;
Attaining mastery over the buddhas' dharmas;
Their subtle intentions are able to enter the various Dharma gates;
The head of the bodhisattvas surpasses all causes and conditions;
Self-mastery in the path, in all samÄdhis and meditative absorptions, their intentions firmly abide in the adornments and transformations;
Embracing the vows of past lives, teaching and transforming beings without ever resting;
These are the ten pure natures of the bodhisattvas.
Bodhisattvas have ten things at the proper time.
What are the ten?
When bodhisattvas practice giving, they give everything without any hope of reward.
They uphold all precepts, and their virtue of restraint is pure and diligently practiced. They do not despise others.
For the sake of sentient beings, they endure all anger, resentment, and hatred.
They eliminate the notion of self and others and universally cultivate diligence, without turning back in accordance with circumstances.
They guard their body, speech, and mind without forgetting, and abandon all worldly affairs, entering into meditation and concentration.
They follow the correct path of liberation and spiritual powers, and do not abandon the afflictions and attachments of the desire realm.
If they are able to practice the perfections and accumulate merit without ever slacking off, they cultivate great loving-kindness.
They understand that there are no sentient beings, and they take on the suffering of the five aggregates. They do not abandon great compassion.
They understand that all phenomena are naturally tranquil, and they awaken to the ten powers of the TathÄgata in accordance with circumstances.
Using limitless suitability to reveal to the people, turning the Dharma wheel without ever turning back, seeing others' aspirations and teaching them;
These are the ten timely matters for the bodhisattva.
The bodhisattva abides in this and attains the Buddha's unsurpassed great wisdom, and is then able to be timely.
The bodhisattva's faith and understanding also has ten matters.
What are the ten?
Faith in the subtle and always following what is appropriate;
Virtuous roots that are difficult to attain, sincerely practicing innumerable various pure deeds;
Their fondness is vast and all-encompassing, seeing the innumerable minds of sentient beings;
Faith in quiescence, entering the profound and ultimate Dharma gate;
Delighting in purity, giving rise to a vast mind, loving and respecting what is hoped for;
Because the buddhas establish the ten powers, being humble and respectful without compare, subduing the mÄras and their retinue;
Ultimately delighting in good deeds, being equal to karmic retribution;
Sincerely approaching the gate, manifesting according to their preferences;
Receiving what is received means wishing to attain the Buddhas' predictions;
With spiritual powers and freedom, one can do as one pleases, and if one wishes to attain Buddhahood, one will immediately achieve perfect enlightenment;
These are the ten matters of the bodhisattvas' faith and understanding.
Bodhisattvas have ten matters in their faith and understanding of entering the world.
What are the ten?
Faith that all Buddha lands enter a single world;
Faith that a single world enters all Buddha lands;
Faith that a single lotus flower is like the trichiliocosm, and a single TathÄgata's body pervades and sits upon it in the Buddha lands of the ten directions;
Understanding and faith that all is naturally like empty space;
All worlds are universally adorned;
Faith that they enter the ten directions, and the bodhisattvas' bodies can pervade them;
Faith that the lands of the ten directions are established in a single trace;
All worlds enter a single person's body and are self-expressive;
The Buddha lands reach the TathÄgata tree, and the Way of the Dharma assembly is universal;
With a single sound, they can inform all sentient beings in the ten directions, and those who hear it are delighted in their hearts;
These are the ten things by which bodhisattvas have faith in and enter the world.
Being able to abide in this, they can enter the immeasurable lands of the TathÄgatas.
Bodhisattvas have ten things by which they enter the realms of sentient beings.
What are the ten?
All bodily forms are naturally formless;
The realms of all beings are then a single body;
Freely lecturing in the Dharma hall, they have faith in the place they enter;
All the various kinds of beings then enter the belly of a single bodhisattva;
The realms of all beings take on the forms and appearances of Åšakra, BrahmÄ, and the Four Heavenly Kings;
They have faith that the realms of sentient beings enter the body of the TathÄgata;
The people of the ten directions, crawling creatures, those who breathe, and those with human bodies enter the body of a single person;
All sentient beings are able to abide in a single category of the Buddha's teachings;
They manifest the realms of all beings, appearing as the forms and appearances of Å›rÄvakas and pratyekabuddhas, forever without thought or concept;
They manifest the adornments and merits of bodhisattvas in the worlds of the ten directions;
In the realms of sentient beings, they manifest the forms, characteristics, various bodies, and dignified deportment of the TathÄgata, teaching and guiding the multitudes.
These are the ten matters of bodhisattvas entering the realms of sentient beings.
Bodhisattvas have ten abodes.
What are the ten?
Giving rise to the bodhi mind is their abode;
Cultivating the roots of virtue and ceasing various evils;
Transforming sentient beings and guiding them in a timely manner;
Always seeing the buddhas and not leaving the sages;
Wherever they wish to be born, they immediately attain that abode;
In the pure realms, they cultivate the practices of the Way;
Not deviating from true reality, always maintaining the correct vows;
Not following deviant oaths, they all can follow and uphold the six pÄramitÄs;
Single-mindedly contemplating the Dharma of the equal Way;
Wherever they roam, they meet with the buddhas;
These are the ten abodes of bodhisattvas.
Bodhisattvas dwelling here abandon all defilements without remainder, and attain the TathÄgata's immeasurable wisdom abode. This is their dwelling.
Bodhisattvas have ten things. With these they sever all arising activities.
What are the ten?
The arising of the realm of sentient beings, they open and transform them, causing them to reach the ultimate;
If the world arises, they eliminate its defilements, always causing it to be pure and clean;
The arising of the TathÄgata's appearance and attaining bodhisattva practices;
The arising of various meritorious roots, accumulating the Buddha's marks;
Arising with great compassion, eliminating the suffering and distress of sentient beings, the decline of the five aggregates;
Giving rise to great compassion, encouraging sentient beings to establish all wisdom;
The perfections gathering and accumulating the bodhisattva's pure practices;
Giving rise to skillful means, universally for all, manifesting the gate of moral virtue;
Giving rise to the intention of the Way, the mind is vast and boundless;
To take the essentials and say:
All dharmas are what the bodhisattva gives rise to, manifests, and comprehends with spiritual powers;
These are the ten things that the bodhisattva gives rise to.
The bodhisattva has ten things that he practices.
What are the ten?

Always thinking of the perfections, practicing the precepts without deficiency, following the wisdom of the sages without following false views, conforming to propriety without ever losing the proper time, upholding the Dharma without following false views, following the sequence of time without contradicting the proper time, manifesting in a timely manner without violating the teachings, practicing the meaning and not being weary of instruction, practicing correct enlightenment and not following the lesser vehicle, and following the practice of the sages and turning the Dharma wheel; these are the ten things that the bodhisattva practices.
The bodhisattva has ten things that he accomplishes.
What are the ten?
Always harboring sincerity;
Respectfully serving good friends and accomplishing the Buddha Dharma;
Earnestly loving and delighting in what the TathÄgata says, never slandering the correct scriptures and teachings;
Their minds are immeasurable, abiding in the boundless;
Encouraging and assisting in the roots of virtue, they attain the realm of the TathÄgata without limit;
Faithfully and joyfully without doubt, they are able to enter the worlds of the ten directions and become the Buddha's teachings;
Moreover, in the Dharma realm they are unshakable, their minds like Mount Tai;
Shaking the realm of MÄra, they are not at ease, naturally subdued;
They always recognize and remember the realm of the buddhas;
Instructing sentient beings, they should think of the TathÄgata's ten kinds of wisdom-powers;
These are the ten accomplishments of the bodhisattvas.
Bodhisattvas have ten things that lose the Dharma of the Buddha's path, and they should always stay far away from them.
What are the ten?
Being arrogant and despising good friends, they lose the Dharma of the Buddha's path;
Fearful of birth and death, the suffering and distress of poverty;
Disliking and wearying of practices, going against the bodhisattva mind;
Wearying of going around and stopping in the world;
If one's conduct is contrary to one's nature, one will lose the level path of right concentration;
The roots of virtue one has created, one thinks:
This was done by me.
Jealousy and slander of the true Dharma;
Concealing and covering up the practices of bodhisattvas;
Taking delight in the Dharma of Å›rÄvakas and pratyekabuddhas;
Disdaining the vast conduct, not rejoicing in proclaiming the great Dharma of bodhisattvas.
These are the ten dharmas of losing the path for bodhisattvas. One should always stay far away from them in order to enter the unsurpassed sagehood of bodhisattvas.
Bodhisattvas have ten things in their tranquility.
What are the ten?
They are always diligently cultivating the perfection of wisdom;
Observing sentient beings, eliminating their delusions;
Liberating all from the bonds of wrong views;
Never giving rise to thoughts seeking various delusions, teaching and transforming those who are attached to and covet various delusions;
Transcending the three realms, wandering through all the worlds in the ten directions, dwelling within them;
They transform sentient beings who are greedy for various afflictions and who indulge in negligence, causing them to abandon the Dharma of desire and love;
They arouse great compassion and pity for all beings, eliminating all that exists and yet manifesting all relatives;
They shake all worlds, manifesting birth and death, in order to demonstrate practice;
They play in worldly dharmas without attachment, and yet they enter into them in accordance with the times to teach;
They fully see the Buddha way, not cutting off the great practice, not fearing their original vows.

These are the ten kinds of quiescence of the bodhisattvas, transcending the world through the holy path, embracing and protecting the people, surpassing the practices of Å›rÄvakas and pratyekabuddhas.
Bodhisattvas have ten things by which they attain the ultimate Dharma.
What are the ten?

To be born on the ground of self-mastery, to reach the realm of all buddhas, to accomplish the bodhisattva's work, to be replete with all perfections, to flourish and fill the buddha lineage, to transcend the ranks of the tathÄgatas, to always establish the ten powers of the buddhas, to ultimately reach the great way of the tathÄgatas, to understand that all buddhas have a single dharma body, and to practice without duality as a tathÄgata or arhatâ€”these are the ten ultimate dharmas of the bodhisattva.
Bodhisattvas have ten things that give rise to the buddhadharmas.
What are the ten?
First, single-mindedly taking refuge and revering good friends gives rise to the buddhadharmas up to the root of a single virtue;
Faith and joy in the Buddha's teachings then give rise to the path;
In the time it takes to form an intention, one is able to manifest all the practices of the tathÄgatas;
By attaining the boundless great vow, one gives rise to an expansive mind;
Delighting in one's own root of virtue, one establishes it without forgetting or losing it, and never suffers from it;
Accumulating practices for innumerable eons, they encompass all that will come in the future;
Roaming and dwelling in immeasurable buddha-lands, they transform sentient beings, always in accordance with the season, giving rise to bodhisattva practices, without ceasing to tread the path;
Always giving rise to great compassion, manifesting immeasurable resolve, in a single thought they universally see the void;
Having attained transcendent entry into the sublime great practice, giving rise to true aspirations, not losing their original intention;
Upholding all the teachings of the tathÄgatas, illuminating sentient beings and giving rise to the aspiration for enlightenment, replete with the Dharma of myriad virtues;
These are the ten dharmas for the bodhisattva to give rise to.
The bodhisattva has ten things that are called the correct man.
What are the ten?
The bodhisattva understands the Buddha's wisdom as the one Dharma body, thus he is called the opener of the path;
Firmly abiding in the Great Vehicle, he is called the great man;ğŸ”½Upholding the majestic Dharma, he is called the venerable person;
Awakening to the wondrous Dharma, he is called the sage;
Entering the supreme wisdom, he is called the transcendent man;
Encouraging others to be diligent is called a superior person;
Proclaiming the supreme Dharma is called unsurpassed;
Fully understanding the ten kinds of powerful wisdom is called a powerful one;
Removing all darkness and obscurations is called matchless;
A peerless person who attains mental freedom and immediately achieves Buddhahood is called inconceivable;
These are the ten epithets of the bodhisattva-mahÄsattva.
There are ten things in the bodhisattva's path.
What are the ten?
The bodhisattvas' path is the same as the path of the One Vehicle, without compare, and they do not abandon the one mind.
The bodhisattvas' practice is the path of wisdom and skillful means, which are two natures.
There are also three paths:
Cultivating emptiness, signlessness, and the root of wishlessness, without beginning or end, not relying on the unconditioned, and roaming in the three realms without being defiled.
There are also four paths:
Cultivating the practice of bodhisattvas, expounding inexhaustible karma;
All able to encourage and assist all merits;
Bowing to the TathÄgata, revering him without slacking;
Encouraging and assisting the holy wisdom, skillfully proclaiming the teachings of the Way.
Increasing the path of the five faculties:

Firmly establishing the faculty of faith, greatly diligent in all practices, abiding in an undistracted single-minded state without turning back, skillfully discerning and following concentration, always clearly understanding the practice of wisdom.
Cultivating the six supernormal powers as the path:
With the heavenly eye, one sees all forms and appearances, and observes the various types of sentient beings in all worlds, whether they are being born or dying;
Then, with the heavenly ear, one hears the sÅ«tras spoken by the buddhas and upholds them;
Seeing other sentient beings, one is able to discern them, seeing one's own mind and also observing the intentions of others, with countless thoughts that can be accomplished by oneself;
Recalling the innumerable eons of the past, the roots of virtue that were created, and the appropriateness of increasing benefits, one fully understands them all;
They attained great spiritual powers and manifested various transformations in accordance with the fundamental teachings of sentient beings, thereby instructing sentient beings with the true Dharma;
Their wisdom exhausted all defilements, and they saw the fundamental limit of existence, yet they did not cease the practices undertaken by bodhisattvas.
The seven contemplations are the path of the bodhisattva:
Constantly contemplating the Buddha, the guide of sentient beings, who is boundless, and seeing and upholding all phrases, encouraging others to take refuge in the Buddha;

Contemplating the sutra Dharma, the Tathagata, who has never moved from the single seat of enlightenment, yet is present in all buddha assemblies manifesting and expounding the Dharma, with his voice pervading the ten directions;

Knowing the mental faculties of all beings and guiding them, their thoughts contemplating the Sangha of innumerable bodhisattvas who are irreversible, seeing those who are not counted as numerous, and seeing all beings;
The bodhisattva body always contemplates giving, giving to all bodhisattvas, equally controlling their minds, contemplating great giving to increase virtue;
Always thinking of the precepts, not abandoning the bodhisattva mind, and using all meritorious roots to give to all sentient beings;
Always thinking of the heavens, bodhisattvas are born in Tuá¹£ita Heaven and will attain the position of a buddha in their next life;
Hungering and thirsting for virtue, always thinking of sentient beings, using great skillful wisdom to transform sentient beings, and being unable to be hindered in eloquence.
The eightfold right path:
Following right view and abandoning all wrong views.

Abandoning all false thoughts and greedy seeking, always thinking of the wisdom of all spiritual powers, the moral character and family lineage, abandoning the four faults of speech, cultivating the noble lineage, proclaiming and transmitting right speech, and using one's body to give to sentient beings, tirelessly instructing and teaching all people, and not abandoning the right precepts.

As for right action, firmly abiding in self-mastery, being content with tranquility, cultivating moral character, abiding in propriety and deportment, abiding in the right Dharma, and not making mistakes.

The right skillful means is for all bodhisattvas, who are like brothers born of the same womb, to see their relatives without loss, and to follow and cultivate the ten kinds of powerful practices of the TathÄgata.
The right intention is to be able to uphold all sounds heard, to universally see the buddha-lands in the ten directions, and to be confused about the mind of concentration.
The right concentration is that for all bodhisattvas, the inconceivable is the gate of liberation;

Because of wisdom, with a single mind one pervades countless concentrations, and in the fundamental concentration one always abides in samÄdhi, never abandoning it, which is the path of the bodhisattva.

Departing from the traces of danger in the desire realm, the Dharma that is expounded and spoken is all unobstructed, speaking of what is thought and the attachments of various thoughts, transforming beings and entering all-knowledge, abandoning hopes and abandoning various greed and love, always wishing to contemplate and see all tathÄgatas;

With a joyful mind, never slacking off, abandoning worldly suffering and happiness, manifesting the bodhisattva's noble transcendence of the world, the wisdom of eternal peace, cultivating the understanding of impermanence and formless concentration;

Being born in the desire realm and in the form realm, initially unmoved, transcending all thoughts, sounds, and correct attainments encountered, the bodhisattva practice is not considered troublesome.
If one is able to contemplate the TathÄgata's ten powers, O Buddha's disciples!
Sending forth is the bodhisattva path, always able to understand existence and non-existence, limits and limitless.

Seeing the retribution and rewards of all sentient beings in the past, future, and present, the direction of their sins and blessings, knowing all the faculties of the spirit, clearly distinguishing, examining their fundamental mind and expounding the Dharma for them.

Distinguishing the innumerable different bodies, such as this, with superior aspirations, some in the middle, and some with inferior aspirations, knowing their boundless state and proclaiming the Dharma.
In all lands, all sentient beings in the three times and innumerable eons, the bodies of all bodhisattvas are all present there.

The TathÄgata, the Arhat, manifests without thought, yet does not go against or abandon the practices of all bodhisattvas, the intentions of various meditative absorptions, and single-mindedly receives the dust, afflictions, and anger.

Observing the advance and retreat, knowing the causes of birth, abiding in the bodhisattva gate, seeing the destinies of birth and death of all sentient beings and explaining the beginning and end for them.

Knowing the various thoughts and memories in the three times, entering the one time, understanding the dust, afflictions, obstructions, and the unbinding of the mind of all beings, causing them all to be exhausted, not abandoning the practices that are manifested by the bodhisattvas.
These are the ten paths. The bodhisattvas abide in this and attain the unsurpassed skillful means of the TathÄgata.
The bodhisattva's practices and paths are immeasurable, the paths reach the limitless, the practices are innumerable, pure beyond calculation.
Why is it so?
There are ten things in the bodhisattva's practice of the path that are immeasurable.
What are the ten?

The sky is immeasurable, the Dharma realm is profound and profound, and everything is immeasurable; the types of sentient beings are extremely numerous and inexhaustible; the world is boundless and limitless; all evil thoughts are also bottomless; the words and phrases of all people are also bottomless; the body of the TathÄgata is incalculable; the sounds and teachings expounded by all Buddhas are also inexhaustible; the power of the TathÄgata's path cannot be exhausted; the wisdom and insight of all omniscience are also boundless. These are the ten immeasurables of the bodhisattva path.
Why is it so?
Just as the sky is immeasurable, the cultivation of the path is immeasurable, and it should be like this;
Just as the Dharma realm is profound and profound, the immeasurable adherence to the meaning of the path is also like this;
Just as the realm of sentient beings is extremely numerous and inexhaustible, the inexhaustible adherence to the path by bodhisattvas is also like this;
If the world has no boundaries, the advancement of the path is also like this;
If the various evil thoughts are innumerable, transforming people in accordance with the Way is also like this;
If the words of the common people are boundless, the union with the Way is like this;
If the practices of the TathÄgata are innumerable, all sentient beings have no second country, and what is thought is all-encompassing, the practice of the Way is also like this;

If the Buddha's voice and teachings are inexhaustible, the cultivation of the Way is also like this, and with a single instruction, he universally announces to all the types of beings in the Dharma realm;
If the power of the TathÄgata is inexhaustible, advancing and cultivating the Way with the power of the TathÄgata is also like this;
If omniscience is innumerable, bodhisattvas cultivating the Way by accumulating merit are also like this;
This is the bodhisattvas' immeasurable practice of the path.
Bodhisattvas' practice of the path has ten things.
What are the ten?
There is no practice or non-practice, and there is what is appropriate and what is not appropriate;
The body, speech, and mind do not reach anywhere, there is no elevation or debasement, and their wisdom is originally pure, and thus it is so;

Without acceptance or non-acceptance, practice or non-practice, entering into spontaneity, like an illusion, a dream, a shadow, an echo, a plantain, a flash of lightning, a mirage, the moon in the water;

Having understood this, not relying on anything, realizing that the three realms are empty, without characteristics or aspirations, all without location, arising from thoughts and appearances, there are three places;
Accumulating these merits, not neglecting their practice;
The mind being nonexistent and invisible, without words or teachings, apart from all phenomena;
The dwelling place of the multitude, practicing in accordance with the Dharma realm, without destruction;

Able to know and contemplate, entering all dharmas, not losing the true principle of the TathÄgata's original state - this true principle is universally pervasive, reaching to the limits of space - entering the wisdom, practices, and power of the bodhisattvas, never slackening, the TathÄgata's ten powers and four forms of fearlessness;
The treasury of omniscience observes all that is equal, contemplating all dharmas without hesitation;
These are the ten practices of the bodhisattva's path.
The bodhisattva has ten practices of the path that are pure and bright.
What are the ten?
Buddha's disciple!

The bodhisattva is in the desire realm but does not move, suddenly in the form realm, in its image practice, with the liberation gate of single-minded concentration, the place where he is born is without negligence, this is one pure path.
Moreover, Buddha's disciple!
The bodhisattva sees the vehicle of the hearers and delivers them with wisdom, not falling into that path, this is the second pure path.
Moreover, Buddha's disciple!

The bodhisattva observes and understands the vehicle of the solitary realizers, clearly understanding it according to the time, giving rise to great compassion, attaining the vows of the powers without slacking off, this is the third pure path.
Moreover, Buddha's disciple!

The Bodhisattva Mahasattva was surrounded by a great retinue and followers, with hundreds of thousands of musical instruments played by the celestial people, and countless jade maidens playing the qin and se, their sounds clear and harmonious, in a great carriage.
The Bodhisattva was in the midst of this, in the meditation liberation gate, in the samÄdhi absorption, like the path without obstruction, this is the fourth pure path.
Moreover, child of the Buddha!

The Bodhisattva, in the singing and dancing of all beings, following the actions of the assembly, demonstrating to be the same as them, always like a single mind, the Bodhisattva's concentration never once disturbed, this is the fifth pure path.
Moreover, child of the Buddha!

The Bodhisattva has already transcended worldly dharmas, and within all activities has nothing to which he is attached, not abandoning the path of transcendence, rescuing and embracing sentient beings, this is the sixth pure path.
Moreover, child of the Buddha!

Bodhisattvas abide in the path, manifesting sagely wisdom to enter the right path, transcending all wrong views, and in the wrong paths, instructing sentient beings to be liberated. They do not associate with the wrong paths, this is the seventh pure path.
Moreover, child of the buddhas!

The body, speech, and mind of bodhisattva-mahÄsattvas are without deficiency or leakage, and they do not guard the precepts. They nurture the pure prohibitions of the TathÄgata, manifesting pure conduct for the foolish and ignorant among ordinary beings, and teaching those with evil precepts to universally possess all pure blessings.
Wherever bodhisattvas go, they eliminate the paths of hell, hungry ghosts, and animals, and bring about the three wholesome paths.

Not being at ease in the present, they are born in places of many difficulties and poverty, and wherever they go, they liberate sentient beings. Although they roam within that, they do not associate with it, this is the eighth pure path.
Moreover, child of the buddhas!

The bodhisattvas do not rely on others, but in the Buddha's teachings they attain unobstructed eloquence. They universally contemplate the buddhas and attain the light of Dharma wisdom. The tathÄgatas are without form, and all buddhas have the same Dharma body.
The buddhas guide and benefit for the sake of all, universally illuminating the Dharma gate, equally abiding in the various vehicles. The abodes of the buddhas are all present before one's eyes.
All sentient beings are all incapable. The faces and hands of sentient beings all see forms that have never existed before. They are all universally equal. The Dharma they seek is never forgotten.
The teachers they manifest, from whom they receive, they all respectfully rise to welcome and reverse, and because of their strangeness, they receive it.
The Dharma they cultivate is in sentient beings.
Why is it so?
Skillful means.

The bodhisattvas' practices and the true reality of the pioneers abide in the path of action. They always use skillful means to cause sentient beings to attain the teachings in accordance with the precepts, manifesting the path of skillful means so that each can attain their proper place. This is the ninth pure path.
Moreover, O Buddha-Son!

The bodhisattvas gather the roots of virtue and attain the supreme and wonderful Dharma of the bodhisattvas. They fully possess the practices of the TathÄgata's stage of abiding, the utmost that can be attained by all Dharma-honored ones. They are bound to the Dharma crown of immeasurable purity, with the sash of right silk.
They manifest the bodies of innumerable tathÄgatas in the worlds of the ten directions, without loss or decrease, and establish the wheel of the Dharma.
Their bodies completely pervade all buddha-lands, roaming through the dharmas, alone treading the three realms, crossing to the other shore, and attaining mastery over all bodhisattvas.

In the lands of the ten directions, in the past, present, and future, the buddhas manifest and teach and transform sentient beings, all in a single buddha-land, without contradicting the practices of the bodhisattvas, without confusing the wisdom of the path, without contradicting the fundamental virtues of the bodhisattvas, and without retreating.

They tread the bodhisattva path without turning back, engage in the practices of the great beings without slacking off, and also do not abandon the acceptance of the correct men, do not abandon skillful means, do not neglect the holy work, do not contradict the power of the bodhisattvas' practices, do not harm others, and do not go far from the correct practices established by the holy men.
Why is it so?
Thus, the bodhisattva quickly attains the unsurpassed true path.
In this way, the bodhisattva practices without attachment, observes all wisdom, and illuminates the formless body of the TathÄgata, which is these ten pure paths.
The bodhisattva, dwelling in this, quickly attains the unsurpassed great path of the TathÄgata.
Buddha's disciple!
Bodhisattvas have ten kinds of practices.
What are the ten?
Cultivating precepts, with great vows and extraordinary, gradually perfecting;
For diligent practice, embracing all the meanings of the path without turning back;
Following the practice of spiritual powers, according to the intentions of the masses, making them all rejoice;
Cultivating the practice of spiritual powers, universally entering the buddha lands of the ten directions, combining them into one realm without moving;
Aspiring to pure and harmonious, attaining entry into the marvelous;
Vows firm and solid, all that is done is accomplished;
If receiving submission and victory, not transgressing the commands of all honored teachers;
Seeking to hear the scriptures, practicing without weariness, reverently cultivating the Dharma expounded by the buddhas without considering it troublesome;
Venerating the holy nature of the Dharma, roaming in all the assemblies and sites of enlightenment, courageous and unafraid;
Approaching the ultimate, with great practice and purity, understanding that all are unproduced - these are the ten practices.
Bodhisattvas dwelling in this [stage] can roam through all buddha lands in the ten directions without obstruction.
Bodhisattvas have ten kinds of hands.
What are the ten?
They are:
The hand of firm faith, believing in the teachings of the TathÄgata, with single-minded faith and joy that is inexhaustible;
With the hand of making offerings to the buddhas and pratyekabuddhas, accumulating great merit and increasing it without weariness;
The hand of giving up, causing all those who seek to be delighted and fulfilling their wishes;
The hand of praising good words and first asking after one's well-being;
The hand of extensive learning and skillful means, severing all doubts, entanglements, and nets, and being tranquil in the three realms;
The hand of great roaming, with the hand of love and desire being impermanent, transforming the realm of sentient beings and bestowing what is given;
The hand of abiding in the stage of peace, realizing the four streams, with the arm of crossing to the other shore completely encompassing the inner treasury;

To uphold impartial conduct as the Dharma without a teacher, to transform all beings without a harmful mind, to expound the scriptures, to clearly understand worldly and transcendent dharmas, to be able to eliminate all calamities and illnesses of body and mind with the hand,
to extinguish afflictions with the hand of the treasure of wisdom, and to manifest the radiance of immeasurable dharmas;
These are the ten matters of the bodhisattva's hand, which extensively covers all with this path of the hand.
The bodhisattva's abdomen has ten matters.
What are the ten?
They are:
The abdomen of resolve, whose thoughts are pure and harmonious;
The treasury of straightforwardness without flattery or deceit, not thinking of false adornments, and having nothing to accept;
The realm without causes and conditions, not delighting in any existent karmic activities;
Eliminating all afflictions, with wisdom as the womb;
The mind being pure and without flaws;
Contemplating the cessation of all food, thinking of the true meaning of dharmas, and observing that myriad things are nonexistent;
Understanding the twelve links of dependent origination, they discern all the karmic activities of birth and death;
Their disposition is gentle and pure;
They eliminate all extreme wrong views;
For the womb of bodhisattvas, they cause sentient beings to enter the treasury of the Buddha's path;
These are the ten matters of the womb for bodhisattvas.
Bodhisattvas also have ten treasuries.
What are the ten?
Not severing the Buddha's teachings, abiding in the bodhisattva practices, upholding the Buddha's teachings, and attaining birth through being heedful and causing the Dharma teachings to flourish;
For the womb of bodhisattvas, abiding in supreme wisdom, manifesting in the world and following the holy assembly;
For the womb of bodhisattvas, abiding in irreversibility and turning the Dharma wheel, necessarily coming from the remaining wholesome dharmas of sentient beings;
For the womb of bodhisattvas, abiding in accordance with the time, not missing the opportunity of the path, and ultimately guiding those sentient beings who are in uncertain states;

For the sake of the bodhisattva womb, establishing karmic retribution, each causing them to be liberated, and preventing their extinction, sentient beings dwell in places of wrong views, giving rise to great compassion;
For the sake of the bodhisattva womb, giving rise to the future boundless light of the TathÄgata's ten powers, practicing and upholding karmic retribution to make them complete;
For the sake of the bodhisattva womb, subduing the mÄras, with virtue and basis unmatched, with great fearlessness, making the lion's roar;
Then the bodhisattva womb, in one dwelling place, joyfully gladdening sentient beings, causing them to have no remaining doubts, attaining the eighteen dharmas of the buddhas;

For the sake of the bodhisattva womb, all using the wisdom of the holy path to benefit all, all sentient beings in the lands of the ten directions having the buddhas' teachings, encouraging and assisting the buddhas' path;
For the sake of the bodhisattva womb, being born without distinction, entering into one wisdom;
These are the ten wombs of the bodhisattva.
The bodhisattva's mental activities have ten things.
What are the ten?
Whatever karmic activities one thinks of, all that one does will be accomplished;
One's mind will not be timid, and one will accumulate merit and practice to perfect the major and minor marks;
One will have great compassion and subdue all mÄras and their retinues;
One will practice compassion in a timely manner and eliminate all afflictions and desires;
One will cultivate the practice of non-retrogression and non-returning with great compassion;
One will reach the site of Buddhahood, which is originally pure and radiant, with no destination in mind and nothing to rely on;
One will enter the minds of sentient beings with compassion and teach them according to their preferences;
One will cultivate the great brahma conduct, enter the Buddha's teachings, not delight in other paths, and save sentient beings;
One will realize emptiness, signlessness, and wishlessness, and attain the absence of anything, eliminating all wrong views without abandoning the three realms;

One will raise all adornments, making them as solid as the vajra realm, indestructible, so that even if all beings were to become mÄras, they would not be able to move a single hair of the bodhisattva's virtuous conduct;
These are the ten compassions.
Bodhisattvas have ten kinds of virtuous armor.
What are the ten?
Wearing the armor of great compassion, they protect all people;
Cultivating boundless compassion, they endure all suffering;
The armor of vows and aspirations, they are able to thoroughly understand all skillful means;
The armor of encouraging virtue, they personally serve the pure practices of the Buddhas;
The armor of generating merit, they cause all sentient beings to receive its grace;
The perfections all deliver the multitude of people;
The armor of holy wisdom, it eliminates all afflictions and desires;
Skillful means plant the roots of various merits;
Guiding and benefiting the universal gate, the mind of omniscience is at ease and not agitated, its intention unchanging;
The armor of single-minded virtue, the mind harbors thoughts of the Dharma and does not forget them;
These are the ten virtuous armors of the bodhisattvas for subduing the multitude of demons.
Bodhisattvas have ten kinds of staffs.
What are the ten?

Using the staff of giving, they harm all stinginess and greed; cultivating the practice of precepts, they destroy all evil deeds; equally encouraging the staff of Dharma, they eliminate delusions; then using wisdom, they cut off sentient beings' afflictions and desires; using the staff of right action, they distance themselves from all ignorance and wrong livelihood; using the staff of skillful means, they universally manifest themselves in lust, anger, and delusion. Bodhisattvas all use the staff of Dharma to digest all sentient beings' desires and faults; those in birth and death then use the power of wisdom to cut off defiled conduct and transform them; expounding the staff of one Dharma, they destroy all reliance; the gate of omniscience is able to eliminate all rebellious households. These are the ten staffs held by bodhisattvas.
Bodhisattvas have ten things on their heads.
What are the ten?
Being without arrogance is foremost, and none in the heavens or the world can see the crown of their head;
Bowing to teachers and elders, being filial to parents, all in the heavens and the world kneel and bow to them;
The head is the best and most excellent, and the trichiliocosm all look up to it;
The root of many virtues is the foremost, and the beings of the three realms all come to take refuge;
On behalf of all beings, bearing heavy burdens, the head is always able to raise its head and look around in the ten directions;
Not despising others' heads, one's actions and steps are extraordinary;
The head of the perfection of wisdom has the Dharma King on top;
The head of skillful means universally manifests the practices of equality of all beings;
The head of transforming people guides and advances beings, causing them all to be universally at ease;
The head of cultivating the teachings of the TathÄgatas always reveres the Three Jewels, causing them to be uninterrupted;
These are the ten heads of the bodhisattva.
The bodhisattva's eyes have ten things.
What are the ten?

With the flesh eye, they see all forms; with the heavenly eye, they universally see the thoughts in the minds of sentient beings; with the wisdom eye, they observe the faculties of the people; with the Dharma eye, they see the ultimate truth of all phenomena; with the eye of right enlightenment, they see the TathÄgata's ten powers; with the eye of holy wisdom, they see the elimination of all unwholesome things; with the eye of light, they emit the Buddha's radiance and illuminate everywhere; with the eye of guidance, they abandon all arrogance; with the unconditioned eye, what they see is unobstructed; with the eye of omniscience, they universally see all Dharma gates in the ten directions. These are the ten eyes of the bodhisattvas.
Bodhisattvas have ten kinds of ears.
What are the ten?
Hearing praise of virtue, they sever all attachments;
If they hear slander, they eliminate all that is received;
If they hear the matters of Å›rÄvakas and pratyekabuddhas, they are neither delighted nor aspire for them;
If they hear praise of the bodhisattva practices, they will be overjoyed;
They will block off the hells, hungry ghosts, and animals;
If they are born in poverty or the eight difficult situations, they will arouse great compassion;
If they hear of being born in the heavens and the peace of the human realm, they will know that all is impermanent and aspire to the great path;
If they hear praise of the merits of the buddhas, they will redouble their efforts to perfect this practice;
If they further hear of the perfections, the four kinds of generosity, and the bodhisattva Dharma treasury, they will be able to cultivate all of them and penetrate them, mastering these matters.
Buddha's disciples should know:
The bodhisattvas, in the worlds of the ten directions, hear all the principles and practices expounded by the buddhas.
All that they hear, they understand to be non-existent.

Moreover, the Dharma that the bodhisattvas hear with their ears is all of one evenness. From their initial resolve up to sitting under the bodhi tree and becoming a buddha, they never slack off in teaching and transforming sentient beings.
These are the ten matters of the bodhisattvas' ears.
The bodhisattvas' noses have ten matters.
What are the ten?

If they encounter a beautiful fragrance, they do not take pleasure in it; if they encounter a foul stench, they are not disgusted by it. They equally investigate fragrances and stenches without considering them special, and contemplate all fragrances and stenches as being nothing whatsoever.
Clothes, bedding, etiquette fragrances and stenches, lust, anger, and ignorance matters all equally enter these sentient beings with a focused mind.
All the great treasuries, trees, and various fragrances are all contemplated as being without fragrance.
Below, there is no Saá¹ƒjÄ«va Hell, and above, there are the thirty-three heavens.
Among them, all the various famous fragrances are all unattached, and their origins are all explained.
One attains to hear the fragrances of the precepts, observances, and extensive learning of the Å›rÄvakas.
The fragrances of giving, wisdom, and the path and Dharma.
Aspiring for omniscience, the mind never changes.
If one attains the practices of the bodhisattvas, then one cultivates wisdom and the stage of equality with the TathÄgatas.
If one possesses the fragrant wisdom of the TathÄgata's realm, one will not cut off the supreme path of practice of the bodhisattvas;
These are the ten pure fragrances of the bodhisattvas.
The bodhisattvas have ten matters regarding the tongue.
What are the ten?
Speaking of the practices of sentient beings without end;
Proclaiming the immeasurable teachings of the various sÅ«tras;
Praising the merits and virtues of the buddhas without limit;
Singing the boundless eloquence of nirvÄá¹‡a;
Reciting the boundless deeds of the Great Vehicle;
The words spoken from the mouth pervade the ten directions of empty space;
The great radiance illuminates the buddha lands;
The words spoken from the mouth cause each and every sentient being to understand;
The words spoken from the mouth are praised by the buddhas of the ten directions;
All mÄras, external enemies, afflictions, and birth and death are naturally eliminated, reaching tranquil quiescence and non-action;
These are the matters spoken by the bodhisattvas regarding the tongue.
The bodhisattvas have ten matters regarding the body.
What are the ten?
They are:
If they receive a human body, they will use human speech to teach and transform them;
They will also instruct and guide those of non-human forms;
The hells, hungry ghosts, and animals to follow the precepts;
If born with a heavenly body, they will also teach those of heavenly forms, wishing to practice as a heavenly person or a formless god;
Those in training will be inspired with the stage of training, heading towards the unlearned body;
They will manifest the affairs of arhats without attachment;
In the body of a pratyekabuddha, they will guide the pratyekabuddhas to uphold the precepts;
In the form of a bodhisattva, they will reveal the practices of the Great Vehicle;
The Tathagata's wisdom is limitless, and he manifests according to the time, seeing those who are self-important, and inspires them with skillful means;
The Dharma body is without outflows, and has nothing whatsoever, yet universally manifests all bodies;
These are the ten bodies of the bodhisattva.
The bodhisattva has ten mental practices.
What are the ten?
Remembering the various practices of one's past lives;
The root of various virtues establishes their intention, always revering the essential meaning;
What the mind enters, always aspiring to the Buddha's path;
Extending to the ultimate point, having compassion for the bodies of sentient beings;
Mindful without disturbance, cutting off various afflictions;
The intention is radiant, not being the same as the guest-dust;
Mindful of selecting good conduct, observing it according to the time without transgression;
Contemplating sins and merits, not creating misfortune;
Thinking of the roots of various virtues, the faculties are peacefully concentrated, controlling and not being indulgent;
Their intention is tranquil, seeking the Buddha's concentration;
These are the ten intentions of the bodhisattvas.
There are ten things in the bodhisattvas' practice of walking.
What are the ten?
They like to go to Dharma assemblies to listen and receive the meaning of the sÅ«tras, going without sound or obstruction;
Not harboring lust, anger, ignorance, or fear, the mind always solely thinking;
Wherever there is Dharma teaching, it is all for the sake of sentient beings;
In the desire realm, they transform and guide sentient beings;
If they reach the form realm and formless realm, they immediately return by means of the appearance of concentration;
Universally manifesting in the five realms, they instruct and admonish the multitude of beings;
With the wisdom of spiritual powers, they pervade all buddha-lands and see all tathÄgatas, bowing and inquiring after them;
Wherever they tread, it is all for the sake of the Dharma;
For this reason, they attain great wisdom, manifest nirvÄá¹‡a, do not cut off birth and death, and deliver those who revolve [in saá¹ƒsÄra];
Endowed with all buddha-dharmas, they never cease the practices of bodhisattvas;
These are the ten activities of bodhisattvas.
Bodhisattvas dwelling in this [state] have no activity and no non-activity. On this basis, they universally reach the practices of all tathÄgatas and are born alone in the ten directions.
Bodhisattvas have ten places.
What are the ten?
The place of the bodhisattva mind is never forgotten;
Dwelling in the pÄramitÄs, they cultivate their practices;
They do not gather the Dharma assembly out of fullness, but penetrate wisdom;
Abiding in seclusion, attaining great dhyÄna concentration;
In accord with omniscience, virtuous and content, with the tranquility of the sages;
Dwelling in the absence of various thoughts, also without any expectations;
Practicing the Dharma, not straying from the true meaning;
Paying homage to the TathÄgata, then able to fully possess the Buddha's correct enlightenment and dignified deportment;
Emerging from the place of spiritual powers, fully mastering great wisdom, and attaining the acceptance of the Dharma, fulfilling the wisdom bestowed;
Sitting in the place of the Way, attaining the powers and fearlessnesses, filling all the Buddha's teachings;
These are the ten places of the bodhisattva.
The bodhisattva has ten seats.
What are the ten?
His blessings enable him to attain the seat of a wheel-turning king;
Cultivating the ten virtues, he does not lose the heavenly and human realms;
Attaining the four heavenly kings, he uses the honored Dharma of the Buddha to bestow upon the heavenly beings;
Attaining to be the heavenly emperor, surpassing the masses, BrahmÄ Heaven, and the Independent Heaven;
Desiring to control the minds of others, he also attains mastery over himself;
They ascend the lion seat and manifest the Dharma assembly;
They attain the seat of the true Dharma and achieve the power of dhÄraá¹‡Ä«, illuminating everywhere;
Their resolve is firm and strong, and their correct vows pervade everywhere, penetrating the ten directions;
With the seat of great kindness, they cause those with anger and resentment to attain a joyful countenance;
With the seat of great compassion, they endure all suffering and distress without regarding it as a hardship;
Seated on the vajra seat, they subdue the mÄras and all external enemies;
These are the ten seats.
Bodhisattvas have ten things when lying down to sleep.
What are the ten?
They are peacefully still, with body and mind tranquil, sleeping in solitude;
Contemplating in accordance with the meaning, not missing the right time;
Abiding in right concentration, with body and mind silent;
Dwelling in the Brahma heaven, able to delight themselves and others;
Skillfully cultivating their practices, yet not giving rise to distress in the afterlife;
With the conduct of equanimity, not harboring anger;
Abiding in the practice of the Way, understanding and reaching good friends;
In the subtle and wonderful abode, encouraging and assisting the roots of virtue;
All attaining the source of all principles, being able to ultimately;
Accomplishing the teachings of the Way, not benefiting from wealth and occupation, this is the virtue and practice cultivated in past lives;
These are the ten matters of the Bodhisattva's lying down and sleeping.
The Bodhisattva's room has ten matters.
What are the ten?
The room of ultimate kindness, with an equal mind towards sentient beings;
Practicing great compassion, not looking down on those who have not yet studied;
Practicing great joy, eliminating all unhappiness, with a pleasant and cheerful countenance;
Practicing great protection, being equal towards the conditioned and the unconditioned;
The perfections, with the mind of the Way as the foremost;
Fully practicing emptiness, understanding and clarifying according to the time;
